title: Floods and Heavy Rain
summary: Stronger storms are overflowing rivers and wetlands, affecting homes and schools.
content: Uganda's rainfall is becoming less predictable. When intense storms arrive, rivers and wetlands fill quickly and flood nearby communities. Floods can wash away crops, damage classrooms, and interrupt learning. Preparing for floods means protecting riverbanks, keeping drainage channels clear, and warning communities early.
keyImpacts: Destroyed crops and farm soil erosion
Damage to roads, bridges, and classrooms
studentActions: Join drainage clean-up days to keep channels open
Share safety tips with neighbors during rainy seasons
Track rainfall changes with a school weather board
localExamples: Flooding along River Nyamwamba in Kasese
Wetland overflows around Lake Kyoga affecting farms

title: Drought and Water Shortages
summary: Longer dry seasons are reducing water for families, crops, and livestock.
content: Droughts are lasting longer in parts of Uganda, especially in the cattle corridor. When rainfall is low, rivers shrink and boreholes dry up. Families walk farther for water and crops fail. Building water storage, planting drought-tolerant crops, and protecting watersheds can ease the impact.
keyImpacts: Livestock stress and reduced milk production
studentActions: Encourage water-saving habits during dry months
localExamples: Dry seasons affecting Karamoja and parts of Teso
Reduced pasture in the cattle corridor

title: Heat Stress
summary: Rising temperatures make it harder to study, farm, and stay healthy.
content: Uganda's average temperatures are rising, bringing more hot days. Heat stress affects students, farmers, and outdoor workers. It can lower concentration in class and increase dehydration. Planting shade trees, staying hydrated, and scheduling activities in cooler hours can help.
keyImpacts: Higher risk of dehydration and heat illness
studentActions: Plant shade trees around school grounds
localExamples: Heat spikes in Northern Uganda
Hotter afternoons in urban centers like Kampala

title: Climate-Smart Agriculture
summary: Farmers need new practices to protect harvests from changing weather.
content: Most Ugandan families depend on agriculture. Changing rainfall and temperature patterns make planting seasons less reliable. Climate-smart agriculture includes mulching, intercropping, and using improved seeds. These methods protect soils and boost harvests even when weather changes.
keyImpacts: Soil fertility loss from heavy rain
studentActions: Start a school garden using mulching
Interview local farmers about new practices
Share tips on composting and soil care
localExamples: Coffee farmers in Mount Elgon adapting shade strategies
Cassava growers using drought-tolerant varieties

title: Health and Climate
summary: Changing climate conditions are spreading disease and health risks.
content: Warmer temperatures and heavier rains can increase malaria, cholera, and respiratory illnesses. Floods can contaminate water supplies, while drought can reduce hygiene. Climate-smart health means clean water access, mosquito net use, and community awareness.
keyImpacts: Increased malaria risk in warmer areas
Respiratory issues from dust and smoke
studentActions: Promote clean water storage at home
localExamples: Malaria outbreaks after heavy rains in Eastern Uganda
Cholera risk in flood-prone districts

title: Lake Victoria and Fisheries
summary: Changing lake levels affect fishing communities and transport.
content: Lake Victoria supports livelihoods for millions. Rising temperatures and changing rainfall can shift fish habitats and lake levels. Fisherfolk may travel farther for catches, and storms can be more dangerous. Protecting wetlands and reducing pollution helps keep the lake healthy.
studentActions: Reduce plastic waste near water bodies
localExamples: Fishing communities in Wakiso and Mukono
Wetland loss around Lake Victoria shoreline

title: Deforestation
summary: Cutting trees increases heat, reduces rainfall, and harms wildlife.
content: Forests regulate Uganda's climate by storing carbon and bringing rain. When trees are cut for charcoal or farmland, soils dry out and wildlife loses habitat. Reforestation and sustainable wood use can slow these impacts.
localExamples: Forest loss around Mabira
Encroachment in Mount Elgon reserves

title: Urban Heat
summary: Cities like Kampala are warming faster because of concrete and traffic.
content: Urban areas trap heat due to buildings, roads, and fewer trees. This is called the urban heat island effect. It makes afternoons hotter and raises energy needs. Planting trees, protecting green spaces, and improving transport can cool cities.
studentActions: Help plant rooftop or courtyard gardens
localExamples: Kampala suburbs with limited tree cover
Heat around busy transport hubs

title: Waste Burning and Air Quality
summary: Open burning releases smoke that harms lungs and warms the planet.
content: Many communities burn trash because collection is limited. Smoke releases greenhouse gases and pollutants. Cleaner waste management, recycling, and community collection points can reduce burning and protect air quality.
studentActions: Talk to leaders about safer disposal
localExamples: Burning heaps in peri-urban settlements
Smoke during dry-season cleanups

title: Clean Energy
summary: Solar, hydro, and efficient cooking reduce emissions and save money.
content: Energy choices shape Uganda's future. Clean energy like solar and mini-hydro can power homes and schools without heavy pollution. Efficient cookstoves use less firewood and reduce indoor smoke. Communities benefit from training and access to affordable technologies.
studentActions: Learn how energy choices affect climate
localExamples: Solar mini-grids in rural districts
Hydropower projects along the Nile
